div.head: Documents
Corporal Harvey W. Wiley's Civil War Diary
div.p: With ample justification Stewart Holbrook declared in his book, Lost Men of American History, that Harvey W. Wiley was one of the most influential Americans of the twentieth century.1 This judgment is based upon Wiley's successful efforts, as chief of the Bureau of Chemistry of the United States Department of Agriculture, to obtain the enactment of the Pure Food and Drugs Act of 1906 and to arouse public consciousness of the importance of honest labeling. "American stomachs and insides generally have been better than they would have been had Wiley not lived and labored."2

Almost half of Wiley's life was spent in Indiana, where he was born October 18, 1844, on a farm in Jefferson County , about six miles from the Ohio River. When Fort Sumter was attacked in 1861, he was between sixteen and seventeen years old and was therefore too young to enlist unless he falsified his age. In his autobiography, which was published shortly before his death, Wiley related: "I was a big husky youth, and could easily have passed for eighteen, but because of my parental training in truthfulness I would not swear falsely as to my age."3 His youth, however, did not prevent him from enrolling, along with his father, in a local cavalry company of the Indiana Legion, a home guard organization. General John Morgan's4 raids into Indiana in July, 1863, gave the Legion an opportunity to see some action, and Wiley's company joined in the pursuit of Morgan, who was able, however, to reach Ohio before the Legion could catch him.

In April, 1863, Wiley informed his father that he wished to go to college. Having received his father's consent, he went to Hanover , but his career there was interrupted in 1864 when he, along with some other Hanover students, enlisted
* William L. Fox is a member of the staff of the history department of Montgomcry Junior College, Takoma Park, Maryland .
1 Stewart H. Holbrook, Lost Men of American History ( New York , 1946), 308
2 Ibid., 310.
3 Harvey W. Wiley, An Autobiography ( Indianapolis , 1930), 158.
4 Brigadier General John H. Morgan (1825-1864), C.S.A. See Conrad H. Lanza, "John Hunt Morgan," Dictionary of American Biography(20 vols., New York , 1943), XIII, 174-175. See also Operations of the Indiana Legion and Minute Men, 1863-4 ( Indianapolis , 1865).
in a volunteer regiment for a period of one hundred days.

According to its record, Company I, 137th Regiment, Indiana Volunteer Infantry, in which Corporal Wiley served, was recruited in Jefferson County by Page J. Pickerell, Jonathan T. Summers, Alexander C. Thorn, and John W. Verry. On May 14, 1864, it went into Camp Carrington at Indian-polis; and on the following day Pickerell was elected captain, Summers first lieutenant, and Thorn second lieutenant.5 Wiley's company spent almost all of its active service at Tullahoma, Tennessee , an important point on the railroad connecting General William T. Sherman's army with the North. Here was a supply depot which had to be protected.

In his diary Wiley recorded his impressions about Tullahoma, its people, and its military importance. An intelligent observer, he also commented on such topics as the peculiarities of the local weather and terrain, picket duty, camp morals, correspondence with his family, his case of measles, and a joyful Fourth of July picnic. The period covered by the diary begins with the entry for May 30 and concludes with that of September 17, 1864.

After his discharge from military service, Wiley returned to his father's farm and a few months later returned to Hanover , from which he graduated in 1867. He died in Washington, D.C. , on June 30, 1930, the twenty-fourth anniversary of the signing into law of the Pure Food and Drugs Act. He was buried in Arlington National Cemetery with full military honors. On his coat was pinned his G.A.R. badge and in his casket was placed his old Civil War forage cap.

div.head: HARVEY W. WILEY DIARY, 18646 May 30th
div.p:
On[c]e more I begin my old habit of keeping [a]
5 Harvey W. Wiley Papers (MSS in the Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. ). In the official records of Indiana Wiley's name does not appear on the roster of enlisted men for Company I, although a Harvey Willey appears in the list for Company B. Furthermore, the officers mentioned in the Wiley papers are those listed in the official records for Company B; they were commissioned on May 14. All members of Company B came from Jefferson County . See Report of the Adjutant General of the State of Indiana (8 vols., Indianapolis , 1865-1869)' III (1866), 312, and VII (1867), 392-394, 401-402.
6 Wiley Papers. To make the entries easier to read, punctuation and paragraphing have been changed; the spelling, however, remains unchanged. No entire entry has been omitted, but parts which were thought to be of little interest, such as references to weather, were left out.
journal not because I have any more desire to do so than formerly but because the exigencies of the service seem to demand it. Good opportunities present themselves. Great inducements are offered that in future days we may refer to the words and actions of the past, regret the follies, smile at the pride and weep at the unimproved opportunities.

Peculiar are the circumstances under which I write. A former time I was an unoffensive youth and a student. Now I am a dangerous animal, in fact a "brave soldier boy." I had intended to write from the day of my enlistment but was unable to procure a book untill this morning, when this was obtained at the small price of 30 cts. at the sutlers "long may they wave." Two weeks and two day[s] have elapsed since we went into camp at Indianapolis and during this time I have been gradualy seeing the Military Elephant in all his grand proportions and in every position.

Camp life agrees with me in every respect physicaly. I get fat on Uncle Sam's bread, meat and coffee and like it better every day. The mental and moral elements are not so predominant as the physical; yet we have a prayer meeting nearly every day which is well attended and chances to read the Bible as much as you want to. The great want is for something to do, but this will probaly be remedied when we get to some permanent station for the regulations prescribe 4 hours drill a day; and this would about employ our spare time. The rest of the time we can devote to reading what little literature we can procure, writing. …

These are nice quarters. We have here a whole reg't. in one house with plenty of room, well ventilated, a writing desk and rack for the muskets to each bunk. The only objections that I could raise to them is that instead of solid boards to lay on, there is only slats, some of which persist in bending in unpleasant proximity to one's back bone and ribs; yet the slats have their advantages, giving a more perfect ventilation and more vacillating bed.
8 o'clock P.M.
Taps have just sounded for going to bed, and I am laying in my bunk allready for the blowing out of the lights which will be in a few minutes.

Elliott7 is my roomate, and we have a first-rate bed prepared for the night. Two good rubber blankets, two small
7 A Wilson Elliot is listed in Company B. Report of the Adjutant General of the State of Indiana, VII, 393.
French tents under us and two army blankets over us. We will sleep sounder than any two feather-bed recruits in the land. The soldier's life is truly desirable. The excitement and expectation fully compensates for all the hardships and a consciousness of doing what we ought to is enough consolation but enough for one day.
Taylor Barracks May 31

It is nearly dinner time now, and we have not left here yet and more than that we have no orders to go as I know of. The orders are very strict here. Even a Colonel can't get out without a pass, and it is next to impossible for any one without shoulder straps to get a pass. I am sorry of this; for I wanted to go down to town and get some Photographs struck off before my uniform got soiled, but I guess I can't succeed.

This is a delightful day neither too hot nor too cold. With a bright sunshine giving life and vigor to everything. The quarters are tastefully arranged. A nice yard thickly set with blue grass too each row of barracks. I was somewhat surprised on coming here at the absense of hills such as I was accoustoumed to see along the river. The country is apparently level on both sides of the river as far as you can see.
Dinner is now ready. All our rations are cooked for us here by a brigade of darkies. All we have to do is to go after them and then devour as much as possible.
3 P.M.

We have orders to march in one hour, but I haven't much faith in their being carried out today. It always takes so long to get a Reg't. started even after the[y] receive the direct order to go. I seen a new part of the "Elephant" today viz. a squad of Negro8 soldiers drilling. They did a great deal better than many white troops I have seen with the same opportunities. Their instructor was also an American citizen of African descent. There is another regiment of Indiana troops here now. The 138 arrived yesterday afternoon. There is also one company of veteran troops in camp and I have
8 Wiley capitalized the word Negro throughout his diary, although it was not customary to do so. Perhaps he was influenced by his father's abolitionist thinking.
heard some say 400 conscripts, but I haven't seen the latter named around as yet and am inclined to doubt its existence here.
Wednesday, June 1st

As I expected, the command for us to remove our quarter[s] to some more Southern clime was not carried into execution yesterday; and at ten o'clock A.M., the time of the present writing, we are still here. The day being very warm I have left my bunk and am laying in the shade of the camp fence enjoying myself hugely. We may leave here today, but I think it is rather doubtful. All I hate about being in camp here is that I don't have any chance of look[ing] around. The fence is built of boards and very high. So you can't see anything but a few spires of some of the churches or other buildings of the city and a few of the surrounding trees.

The boys have a heap of fun at each other's expense, perpetrating all manner of jokes on the unsuspecting. There is rarely any ill-will manifested at any kind of a sell, no matter how bad the victim has been fooled.

There are so many troops in camp now that we have a great deal of trouble in getting our ration at the proper time. We had to wait until nearly eight o'clock this morning for our breakfast, and when it did come the coffee was simply a little colored warm water "but sich is life."
Thursday, June 2 Bowling Green , Ky.

We are on the train on the way to Nashville . We have stopped here for a few minutes. We are just startings[sic]. So I will have to quit. We left Louisville about sundown last night and have had a very pleasant ride so far. We are now just inside of the Tenn. line. Have stopped along side of a train of rebel prisoners going north. They are as hard a looking set as you could find anywhere without uniforms, blankets or anything else. Our boys are now holding a confab with them on matters and things in general.

4½ o'clock P.M. Soldiers' home, Nashville , Ten [n]. We arrived safely here about half after two and were marched out on the commons where we had intended to have encamped for the night, but a violent rainstorm arose, which our commanders with great strategy suffered us to remain
in untill it was pretty well expended; and then as there was not one of us who knew how to pitch his tent, they wisely concluded to bring us here.
The house was formerly a hotel built and owned by the rebel General Zollicoffer.9 Our whole Reg't. is quartered in it and plenty of room for two or three more.

All the way, from a few miles this side of Louisville , to 10 or 11 miles of here the clay was of the deepest red; and the road at a distance gave the appearance of being covered with tan bark. Another uncommon thing was the almost universal prevalence of the sassafras shroub, thousands of acres of improved land being covered with it. I saw many fields planted in corn, in which I could hardly see the ground. I didn't see a school house on the whole route. Every four or five miles there would be a fine house, the residence of some wealthy planter. In the distance a row of Negro quarters and now and then a low dirty hovel, surrounded by half naked little children and a reg't. or two of dogs, marked the dwelling place of the "poor white trash."

At every bridge there is a stockade and a small guard to protect them from being burned by the Rebels. A single company of men in one of these stockades can defend themselves against three times there number with ease.

At different places along the road are groups of refugees, the most dejected and abandoned people that I ever saw. They have made themselves all kinds of shelters. Often the hovels are simply made as big square as clapboards. Contraband are also numerous, and after we get into Tenn. the only happy looking people that I saw.

Nashville has once probably been a pretty town and is yet from a distance. The houses are scattered over a great distance, and the only place that there is any solidity of building is north & west of the state house, which is on a high hill about in the center of the corporation. The hill on which the statehouse is situated along with every other hill in the vicinity of the city is strongly fortified. You may think there is some railroading done at the Union Depot at Indianapolis ,
9 Brigadier General Felix K. Zollicoffer (1812-1862), Confederate officer, had been a political power in Tennessee before the war. Ac-cording to Edd W. Parks, Zollicoffer "as a state-rights Whig… worked steadily for peace and understanding between the sections. …" Parks, Felix Kirk Zollicoffer," Dictionary of American Biography, XX, 659-660.
but it is nothing to what is going on here. All the supplies, recruits, reinforcements, etc. for Gen. Sherman's10 army are shipped from here. And there are now as many as twenty-five engines in counting distance and more arriving and departing continualy.

Nashville is emphaticaly a military town. Everything bears the marks of the United States . You see nothing but U.S. wagons on the streets, U.S. cars at the depots, U.S. houses made out of all the buisiness houses in town, U.S. horses everywhere and U.S. soldiers everywhere else.
All around the city except a little space to the North are camps or forts. I can't form any idea, though, how many troops there are here.
Friday, June 3

There was nothing of importance transpired today. Still rainy and muddy with no prospect of clearing up. Two of our companies left this afternoon for the front of some place between here and there. It is reported that our Reg't. is to be scattered in all directions. Our company is to leave for some point south in the morning. Some say for Tullahoma.
Saturday, June 4 Tullahoma, Ten [n].
We left Nashville this morning about 6 o'clock on the Nashville and Chattanooga R.R. and arrived here 75 miles from Nashville at 3 o'clock P.M.

The first thing of interest after leaving Nashville was the soldiers' cemetery in the southern suburbs of the city. Here sleep thousand[s] of brave boys laying as close together as possible, each grave marked with a nice white board at the head & foot, marked with the name, Reg't. and company. This was the first thing that I have seen since I left home that made me feel bad. As one approached the battlefield of Stone River,11 31 miles from Nashville , everyone was on the "qui vive" to see everything seeable. Three or 4 miles from the main battlefield the marks of the struggle became evident. And now and then groups of graves marked where skirmishers
10 William T. Sherman (1820-1891), at this time a brigadier general in the Union army. He was promoted to major general in August, 1864. Oliver L. Spaulding, Jr., "William Tecumseh Sherman," ibzil., XVII, 93-97.
11 December 30, 1862-January 2, 1863. Kenneth P. Williams, Lincoln Finds a General ( New York , 1949-), 11, 554-555.
had fallen. As soon, however, as we crossed Stone River, you could easily percieve that the fight had been in earnest. Trees were twisted about in all directions, and the bark was peeled off from the bottom up as high as 20 or 25 feet with musket balls. Long lines of graves show where the Union and Rebel dead are buried. There is a monument between the railroad and pike where the hottest fight was and where the most men were killed. Although I knew very well that the battle of Stone River was fought on the ground, yet I could not realize then, nor cannot yet, that the battle was fought here.

Murfreesborough is considerable of a town. The greatest attractions about, however, is the fortifications which are truly formidable. The[y] were begun by Bragg12 before the battle of Stone River and afterwards completed by Rose-crans.13 I don't know how strong they are comparatively, but I should hate to be one of those who would have to storm them. Many other traces of battle are visible which it is not necessary to mention.
Sunday, June 5

I am detailed for patrol duty today. All I have to do is every 3d two hours to walk slowly through the town & camp, preserve order, arest suspicious looking individuals, etc. The duty is light, and all I don't like about it is getting up in the night.

When the sun shines out brightly here, it is easy to realize you are in a southern clime. It is about as hot here now as it ever gets in Indiana. As I get to stay in the shad[e] most of the time, however, I do not feel the full effects of it.
Monday, June 6

This is the first day that I have not been well. Have only an attack, thougl [sic] of the inevitable camp diarreah, which I can starve out in twenty-four hours. I was relieved from patrol duty at 8 o'clock and will not be on again probably for several days.

Tullahoma consists of some half dozen, plain, dwelling houses and one hotel, now used as a hospital. There is not one male citizen in town and only about half a dozen female
12 General Braxton Bragg (1817-1876), C.S.A. Conrad H. Lanza, "Braxton Bragg," Dictionary of American Biography, 11, 585-587.
13 Major General William Rosecrans (1819-1898). Oliver L. Spaulding, "William Starke Rosecrans," ibid., XVI, 163-164.
inhabitants except contrabands of which there is a considerable number. All the men are either in the Rebel or Union armies or else bushwhicking around the country. This was formerly considerable of a place, having 1500 inhabitants; but the houses have all been destroyed except the number above stated, and the inhabitants have dwindled down probaly to less than 100 Whites and Negroes.
Tuesday, June 7

There was a nice rain begining about noon today, which materialy reduced the temperature of the atmosphere. There are still signs of more rain tonight. It is, however, not to be dreaded as our tents do not leak worth mentioning.

I am well again today, the starving process having proved to be a complete cure. Others that were not as sick are yet invalids, many of them worse. Nevertheless, medicine is still in requisition and taken with a faith that cannot be accounted for.

Tullahoma is said to be built on very high ground, 1700 feet above the state house in Nashville . The only objection I have to the situation is the scarcity of water. The wells are very deep and the continual drawing keeps them muddy. There is only one little creek some half mile away where there is any chance to bathe.
Wednesday, June 8th
Expected to go on duty today but was agreeably disapointed. The Lieut. said I was to go on a surveying expedition, but it has not started yet. I hope I will get to go with it if there is one.

We now have four drill per day. Also dress parade at 7 o'clock in the evening. The 23 Mo. which has been encamped here for sometime left for the front this morning. The only troops here now besides our Reg't. are the 4th Ky. Battery and one Co. of the 71 O[hio]. If the Rebs want to make an attack on us, now is the time for them to pitch in. I hardly believe, though, that there will ever be an attack here; for there could be several thousand troops here in a few hours.

Quite a sad accident occured in camp this afternoon. Our second Lieut. accidently killed the Orderly Sergeant of the Co. quartered next to us with his revolver. Supposing all were out, he playfully pointed it at him, telling him that he intended to shoot him. The remark proved only too true, and
he immediatel[y] expired with a ball through his brain. The Lieut. who was the inocent cause of the murder delivered himself up but was released on parole and allowed the privileges of the camp.
Thursday, June 9th
It is considerably cooler too day, wind N.W. with broken clouds obscuring the sun, rendering the atmosphere remarkably pleasant.

If I was to stay in the army long, I would learn to be an early riser; for we have to be up every morning at half past four or else go on extra duty the rest of the day. There are also eight roil calls per day, at every one of which those not on duty must answer to their names. On account of this, the men do not have any opportunity to stroll away from camp.

I was detailed to go to Chattanooga , but owing to the fact that I was previously detailed for the survey which may start any time I was not allowed to go. I think, however, I will yet get to go to Chattanooga . If it is not the case, I will be greatly disappointed.

The companies of the Reg't. were lettered today. Our Company is I. After we were lettered, we had to move our quarters so that we could take the same position in camp that we would occupy in the Reg't. No letter from home yet.
Tullahoma, Tenn. Monday, June 13th

I am on picket duty for the first time yet. No one is allowed to travel here without a pass. Such things appear a little strange at first, but we soon get used to it. But up at home if we had to get a pass every time we went to Madison or Kent , it would be strange indeed.

From passers by this morning I have learned the name of the county that we are in, said name being "Coffee." I asked several about it so as to be sure, and some of them were so ignorant that they didn't know.
The inhabitants almost without exception are dressed in the irrepressible "Butternut." Some few, however, have their "jeans" colored gray in imitation of the Rebel uniform.

A fellow just now came along who wanted to go and take the "oath." I sent one of the pickets along with him for that purpose. After he takes the "oath" he can get a pass to
go at large, for ten days after that time is out he either has to get it renewed or else stay at home, just as he pleases. I have three men with me; and we will have to stand picket for twenty-four hours, keeping watch alternately.

Received a letter from home day before yesterday, which done me an immense amount of good as I hadn't heard from the folks for over three weeks. I wouldn't object too three or four letters a week from home. Wrote a letter home yesterday, which made two for one week.

I was down at the grave yard yesterday and saw two soldiers buried. One from Mo. and one from Ky. Owing to the hardness of the ground, the undertaker said that at the depth of four feet (the regulation depth for burying the dead) a body would never decay. Tis almost like encasing in solid rock.
I must wait now till something "turns up" so that I can continue the writing.
6 P.M.

I had expected that my supper would be sent out to me, but in this I was disappointed. But owing to a fortunate circumstance, I did not suffer. One of the boys hearing a disturbance out in the brush took his gun and went out to we if he could di[s]cover the cause. In this he was eminently successful, said cause being about twenty pigs, wild and fat. The report of a musket was heard by us who had remained, soon after he had left the camp and then all was still. In dread suspense we awaited the final result, but were not long kept in doubt. In about half an [h]our our hero returned bearing as the fruits of his victory the hind quarters of a good sised [sic] pig. It evidently had no owner, for there was no mark of any kind about it. We immediately sent one of our number to camp for a frying pan and some salt, which being obtained, we immediately proceeded to get and eat our supper.
Tuesday, June 14th

8 o'clock A.M. Our time will soon be out. Now the relief is probaly already on its way. During the night we saw "nary [a] Reb" nor no other person. If it just wasn't for staying awake, I would just about as leave stand picket as not.

The citizens say they scarcely ever knew such cold weather in the summertime as there is here now. I know by sad experience that the nights are extremely chilly and before morning without good covering are realy uncomfortable.
Thursday, June 16th 5 o'clock in the morning

I was on picket again last night and yesterday and will be untill 9 o'clock today. Am just opposite where I was the other time on the same road. Yesterday morning the picket guard was doubled and very stringent instructions were given them not to let any one pass in the day time without a pass and at night without the countersign. These instructions were rigidly enforced along the ground where I was on duty.

At this post there are 1 Lieut. & 10 men, three men remaining on duty at a time. About the only events of interest transpiring here are the capturing and shooting of "bushwhackers," some being shot nearly every day. The authorities seem to think this the only way of putting a stop to such practices and no doubt it is. Yet it seems like peculiar operations to me when in the evening late I hear a volley of musketry and know that one or more Rebels are no more. Yet these are every day occurrences and have almost ceased to be talked about.

The two Reg'ts. of Tenn. Cav. that are camped here, which bring in these fellows, kill a great many on the spot where they are captured without any form of trial what ever. The most of them are East Tennesseans and have had their property destroyed and their friends slain by the Rebels. If they had their way about it, they would show no quarter; but they are restrained in some degree by their officers.
Friday, June 17

Considerably warmer today, and I am glad of it, not because I would wish the days to be warmer so much as the nights. These have been continuously cool for the last week or two, causing great discomfort among the pickets.

Am on picket again today. Was not very well this morning but feel better now. This is not as nice a place for a picket post as the others I have been on. There is only a single tree for a shade, and it keeps us moving all the time to keep pace with the shadow. The heat now, however, is less intent for the "Bright luminary of day" is sinking in all the magnificence of superabundant loveliness in the western horizon, tinging all nature with unuterable beauty sublimity. (N.B. This is poetical). I think now I had better quit after such an outburst.
Saturday Morn., June 18th

I hear the drums beating at camp for guard mounting. So we have a prospect of being relieved very soon. The greatest objection I have to this post is its proximity to the small pox hospital, the distance being not more than fifty yards. The convalescents are also taking the liberty to run around at large with their polluted clothes. This is another source of anger to the sentinels stationed here.
Monday, June 20

A pleasant evening this, after a sultry day, threatning a storm the time but never executing. And even now a black rain cloud in the east forbades by its occasional mutterings, a violent storm in some portion of our distracted country. But that does not in the least disturb me; for with my physical system in a good condition, as good at least as could be expected in camp, I can lose myself as it were in my mental being and my mind free from all care of bodily things can soor untrameled in the inexhoutable fields of thought and gather there material for present and future use! Now "ain't that the next thing to the poetical?" Let unprejudiced minds decide.

Well the rain has begun sure enough and with an energy that reminds us of high creeks and orders for children to remain at the house untill further orders and when at last those order[s] came and we were permited, under an escort of the "Old Folks," to go and see the "raging of the waters" it was after its bulk was considerably reduced, our ardor considerably cooled, and our patienc [el considerably worried; and when we returned, it was only as disapointed, wet, and illhumored progenies. Of [course] there were some few exceptions to this general rule, all of which exceptions will ever be remembered with pleasure.

Yesterday was Sunday. In camp at ten o'clock A.M. there was a general inspection of quarters, arms, accouterments, etc. At half past 3 in the afternoon, the Chaplin preached a first-rate sermon, which was listened too attentively by some two or three hundred of the Reg't. His talk was practical; and if the soldiers would all take his advice, what a different Reg't. [we] would have.
Tuesday, June 21

It is now dusk, almost dark. Can hardly see to write. This picket post No. 7 is the most dreary and desolate looking
position I have been on yet, not a road, by-path, or foot print to remind one of civilization, nothing but bushes, briers an[d] long grass to make up the immediate landscape with a dense forest for the remote. Altogether the scenery is decidedly "pleasing."
Wednesday, June 22
This is the first day of commencement exercises.14 I wouldn't object to being there just a little while. But then circumstances forbid.

There is a good deal of wickedness in our Co. but compared with some others in the Reg't. it is saintly. Every time I go on duty, almost without exception, the other men are from other companies; and they are generaly so wicked that the most wicked of our Co. appear good in the comparison. The six men that are with me this time will take the premium for wickedness over all others with whom I have been associated.
Tullahoma, June 25

Got a long letter from home yesterday morning from Mother, Sudie and Zwingie15 inclusive. It contained any amount of good. The same remarks will still apply to the weather that have been given it; for the last week or two, hot is no name for it, unless qualified by some very expressive adjective; and even that would fail to give an adequate idea of its violence. Experience alone can convey its burning.
My paper gave out yesterday, but I expect a supply from home in a few days as I have written for the folks to send me some, which no doubt they will do.

I went on picket again this morning but fortunately exchanged with a man that wanted to go with some of his comrades. So I took his place on patrol, which is much more pleasant than picket duty. I don't go on duty now untill 1 o'clock P.M. 'Tis now a little after 9 A.M.
Monday, June 27

It's very plain that if I don't curtail my writing in some degree, my book will be full ere my time is half out. In
14 At Hanover College.
15 Sudie was Susan Wiley Buxton, a sister; Zwingie was Ulrich Zwingli Wiley, the author's brother. Ulrich later became a judge of the appellate court of Indiana.
such an emergency it would be necessary for me to "change my base" or else execute a "flank movement" or in case both of these fail, to do something else that will be sure to succeed.

There was something strange happened today, and that something was that I was left of [f] duty. When if it had been as it usually has, I would have been placed on, it being the inevitable every other day.
Passed outside the lines today and exchanged coffee for milk. My stomack is in much better condition since I quit drinking coffee, and if I drink any more, it will only be in limited quantities.
Tuesday, June 28

I got a rich treat from home last night, a long letter from Father and Mother and a package containing an Independent and [a] Tribune, on which I have been feasting myself all day. The supplement to the Independent contained a rich sermon by the Rev. H. W. Beecher.16 If the folks would only send me such reading matter every [sic], it would be a great advantage.

I often wish I was a Botanist, for the shrubs and flowers of Coffee Co. as a general thing are entirely new to me. To be sure, we have the inevitable (speaking in common parlance) white blossom, & dog fennel are in great abundance here; but the majority of the wild flowers are unknown to me, both visibly and botanicaly. Huckleberries, blackberries, dewberries, cherries, etc. are in great abundance in the vicinity; but we have little chance of gathering them.
Friday, July 1st
Wrote a long letter to Father yesterday ceturing him on his supposed Fremontism, containing eight pages.

This is realy a pleasant day, at least on picket post No. 1 where I am stationed today. The weather has greatly moderated since the heavy rain day before yesterday. I think it must have rained in Indiana for the cloud came from that direction. Contrabands say all thunder storms here come from the North. This has proved to be true in what few I have witnessed.

list.item: 16 Henry W. Beecher (1813-1887), clergyman and author, who lived in Indiana olis from 1839 to 1847, when he went to Plymouth Church of Brook]isn. Harris E. Starr, "Henry Ward Beecher," Dictionary of American Biography, II, 129-135.

div.p: There was a general muster and inspection of arms and accouterments yesterday. We went on parade with knapsacks packed and every[one] prepared as if for a march and stood up in the hot sun two hours or more while the Col. inspected our arms.
Sunday, July 3

I could not help thinking of a year ago today when the feirce struggle of Gettysburg was raging in all its fury. With these thoughts working in my imagination and curtailing my common sense. I was incited to give effect to the "following effacious effusion:"

quote.p: My thoughts recur on this bright day To a scene a year ago When our brave boys in stern array Were battling with the foe. The din of battle loud and strong Shook Pennsylvania's hills And the blood of patriots swept along Was redning [sic] many rills. A traitorous foe had dared to give A blow on freedom's trust And although patriots ceased to live Yet traitors bit the dust. Oh Gettysburgh! can we forget The deed enacted there Nor can we ever cease regret The brave men now that were. Four thousand patriots brave and true For their country that day died And where they fell the honored dead Lay sleeping side by side. A monument now marks the place where freedom fought and won Each silent hero 'neath its shade His work has nobly done. "Requiescat in pace" Ye heroes every one Another year the end may see Of the work so well begun.

div.p: Monday, July 4th

All hail the natal day of "The Great Republic." We welcome thee with joyful hearts and grateful feelings. We cannot cease to praise and admire the American Congress of 1776 that had the patriotism and moral courage to stand forth undismayed in the delclaration and sustainment of our
national independence. Then let "The wild bells ring out to the wild air." Let the cannons roar and boys shout and old men smile and soldiers fight all in honor of the great day rendered doubly dear in these late times by great victories in favor of those sustaining the principle for which the day is celebrated. The Declaration of Independence, the surrender of Vicksburgh, and the retreat of Lee from free territory—may they ever be remembered and commemorated by all good people.

But to particulars. I was wakened in the morning by the sound of cannon firing a national salute. Came off of duty at nine o'clock. Went to Headquarters and addressed by W. P. Fishback Esq., private 138th Reg't., a Dr. Somebody from Ill., Capt. Elliott from someplace else; but the nice part is to come.

During the day a small picnic party had been organized and after the military display, etc. the following named individuals got a pass outside the lines and retired to the "Big Spring" to enjoy themselves as best they might; G.M. Lodge, A.S. Peck, Andrew Aberdeen, A.D. Wilson, S.W. Elliott, H.W. Wiley17—all of Hanover , Indiana.

On repairing to the destined spot we found a "Superbus Quercus" which spread its magnificent foliage in luxuriant abundance around its trunk, forming a pleasant shade on a beautiful plot of grass, forming every natural comfort necessary for the enjoyment of our party. Here we spread our table with earth's green canopy for a cloth and began immediately to prepare the military necessities that had been collected beforehand.

The scene which soon presented itself before us, was enough to make any patriot shed tears of gratitude (out of his mouth): pies rasberry, pies blackberry, pies huckleberry in profusion, rusks, butter, caned peaches, fresh berries, cream, white sugar, lemonade, etc. Willingly we undertook the part assigned to us, aye without a murmur; and complete was our victory. After the rich repast came the toasts and replies and volleys of wit and wisdom alternately broke forth from all parts of the circle. At last the time came for adjournment and we all returned to camp with light hearts and heavy
17 George M. Lodge, Alexander Peck, Andrew Aberdeen, Andrew D. Wilson, and Wilson Elliott are all listed on the roster of Company B, 137th Indiana Regiment. Reprot of the Adjutant General of the state of Indiana, VII, 392-394.
stomachs. So passed my first 4th of July in a camp, more pleasant than it had ever before.
Friday, July 8th
The drums are beating now for guard mount. The duty comes lighter now on our Reg't. as 4 companies of the 138th are in camp.

A.S. Lee,18 the man in the hospital from our own Co., died yesterday morning and will be buried at nine o'clock. His father was telegraphed for, several days before his death but has failed to arrive.
Sunday, July 10th

Got a letter from home this morning, which was due Friday but passed here and went on to Chattanooga and returned last night. I wrote a long letter to Lizzie19 yesterday about military affairs. Wrote another to Mother last night and this morning.
Gen. Milroy20 is to move his headquarters to Nashville . He and the staff are now waiting at the depot for the next uptrain.
There will be preaching at 3 o'clock this afternoon by a delegate of the Christian commission.
Thursday, July 14th

Our time is half out today, according to the count of the boys; and they are not apt to be wrong about such a matter as that. I returned from an expedish to Duck River yesterday. Went as a guard with a provision wagon. It is about 10 miles from here on a direct line, but some 12 or 14 by the wagon road. I saw some nice field[s] of corn in Duck River bottom, a great deal of it full grown and in silk. I had a good dinner at a house about half way between here and there, which was very acceptable to me and the others.
The 132 City Reg't. arrived here last night and are encamped about half a mile west of us. This arrival revives the rumors about our Reg't. leaving here, but I don't believe anymore of it than usual.

list.item: 18 Alfred S. Lee, ibid., 393.
19 Lizzie was Wiley's oldest sister, Elizabeth Wiley Corbett.
20 Major General Robert H. Milroy (1816-1890) of Indiana. George S. Cottman, "Robert Huston Milroy," Dictionary of American Biography, XIII, 20-21.

div.p: Tuesday, July 19th
'Tis very near time for my breakfast to come around, but I can't see anyone coming with it yet. The other men on the post have had their breakfast a good while ago.
I have to report one of my men today for neglect of duty, for letting the Officer of the day ride nearly up to him without seeing him. It is the first time I have ever had such a thing to do.
Tuesday, July 26, 1864

The "very pleasant night" that I noticed in my last writing "haunts" me still.21 It brought on a severe cold and in a few days an attack of measles, which I haven't gotten over yet. The measles broke out on me Sunday afternoon pretty thickly. They are just beggining to go away today, and I am right smart better but not able to go out of my tent yet.

Got a letter from Sudie this morning giving detailed accounts of home affairs. Our folks were just done cutting hay (July 22). Didn't say whether they had put it up or not, probaly "or not." Will answer her letter tomorrow if I feel able.
I am indebted to the following of my comrades for special favors and attention during my sickness. S. W. Elliott, S. E. Hampton, Lew Ernst22 and many others. They have my warmest thanks.
Thursday, July 28, 1864

I am entirely well of the measles but still have considerable cough and am very weak. Have an excellent appetite and get good things to eat. Have secured some potatoes and soda crackers, which together with the berries and other fruit we get, constitutes all an invalid could desire.
The boys are all out now on battallion drill and have left the tent to the flies and me, principaly the flies.

list.item: 21 On the night of July 18-19, Wiley slept on the ground without a blanket. Since he was on duty, he could not leave his post to obtain one.

22 The company roster indicates that there was a Private Lewis Ernest but no "Ernst" as Wiley wrote in his diary. In the official records of Indiana, this name is also listed in Company B, as is Solomon E. Hampton. Report of the Adjutant General of the State of Indiana, VII, 393.

div.p: Sunday Morning, July 31

This is the last day of July. Tomorrow I suppose our folks will go to the Negro Celebration. I was there last year, but had no idea I would be in Tullahoma a twelve month from then. But such is the fact, and I can't help of thinking where I will be a year hence. The chances are that if I am not drafted nor dead I will be in Indiana. But I cannot tell.
Tuesday, August 2

Yesterday was a very busy day in camp. The Surgeon had recommended a removal of our tents to the Parade ground for Sanitary purposes, thinking that they had remained in their former position long enough. Accordingly the movement began about 9 o'clock yesterday morning and is not finished yet. The "Modus operandi" was for as many to get around a shanty as possible and pick it up bodily and carry it to its new position. There was some hard lifting to do; but it is all done now and there is nothing left to do but clean up the new and old quarters, a task as great as carrying the shanties but not such hard work.
I go on duty tomorrow, [the] first time since I have been sick; but I feel "tantamount" to the undertaking.
Wednesday, Aug. 3, 5 P.M. Headquarters Patrol

This is the first time I have been on duty since I was sick; and I am glad that I got on Patrol, for I can get to sleep in the guardhouse while off duty and thereby keep out of the almost inevitable rain which generaly fall[s] night & day.

There was one of the biggest storms today that there has been since we came here. The wind b[l]ew almost a hurricane and the rain fell in torrents for near[ly] an hour, completely drenching everything not well sheltered. Several of the tents were blown over, and most of them got wet inside.
I am getting along nicely with my Anatomy. Recite several pages daily to Sergt. Hampton, one of my most intimate friends and withal a medical student himself.
Sunday, August 7

There has been no big rain yet today, but from indications and precedents there will be. It has rained every day
now for a week. Three of them have been very hard rains. The rest, little showers.

Had a peach cobbler for dinner too day. Peaches are becoming plenty but are yet very costly. The peaches we put in the cobbler costing 75 cts. Potatoes are $1.50 per busher [sic]. Apples are various prices according to quality.
I am on picket today. Post No. 5. First picket duty that I have done for a long time. So far, it is a nice day, some rainfall this morning but not enough to wet our clothes.
About two more writings will fill up my book, and then I suppose I will quit.
Wednesday, Aug. 10

I see I am very likely to lose my last writing if great care is not taken as it is torn by some unaccountable means. I'm at No. 5 again. [This] makes two times in succession on one post. There has already been one shower today and if appearances are not deceitful, the shower will be in the plural before morning.

I do much of my writing and reading on picket because I have nothing else to do then. In camp my other duties occupy a considerable portion of my time, but here I can give my individual attention to literary pursuits.
Had apple dumplings for dinner today, excellent in quality but rather poor in appearance, their apprenticeship in the camp kettele having given them rather a sable appearance.
Another big train of Rebs passed here today. I suppose nearly a thousand.
Monday, Aug. 15

This is the last writing I will do in this journal. I had thought it would be large enough to answer all my purposes for the "Hundred Days," but in this as in many other things in my life I have been mistaken. I can only say with Byron that "what is writ is writ" and shall neither regret nor exult over what is written.
Our sick are all to be sent home tomorrow as they could not well be sent with the Reg't.
There was quite an alarm here last night caused by someone firing his revolver at some other one. The long roll was beaten, and the reg't. turned out double quick.
This is all. Paper and sentimen[t] alike are at an end.
Tullahoma, Tenn. Friday, Sep[t]. 9

Who would ever have thought that I would have pined an additional few leaves to my diary for the purpose of writing in this town at this late period. But by the kindness of my Phriend Wheeler23 we have been permitted to remain here till this late date. Wheeler cut our communications. On the 30 Aug., the day probaly we would have started home had it not been for his unpleasant proximity, he tore up a good deal of the track between here and Murfreesboro; but the principal damage he did to the road was between that point and Nashville . Just how much damage he did do, we do not know here yet as communication has not been reestablished and there is no telling when it will be. This Wheeler raid has been considerable of a bore on us, for we are shut off from all the world except Sherman's army, which by the way we have good news from.
I have not been well for a fortnight past. My stomach out of order some way. Am better now than I have been.
Tullahoma, Sep [t]. 10

There was great joy in camp yesterday caused by the arrival of the mail from Nashville , the first news we had had from Christendom for a long while. The mail was hauled down from Nashville to Murfreesboro in wagons and thence here by rail. I got one letter from Sudie Morgan, written from Pine Prowe, but where that is I don't pretend to know. I had expected a letter from home by the first mail that come through, but in this I was disappointed. Today, however, the road is opened through to Nashville and there has already two trains gone up; and there will be a train going south at six o'clock this afternoon and very likely there will be another mail and a letter from home, at least I hope so.

I have not written any letters yet since the raid because there has been no chance to send them out, but I believe the
23 Lieutenant General Joseph Wheeler (1836-1906), C.S.A. He was one of the most capable cavalry officers of the war, and for his military ability and murage he was given the epithet of "Fighting Joe." Thomas J. Betts, "Joseph Wheeler," Dictionary of American Biography, XX, 50-52.
mails will go out regular after today. So I have a notion to write home either today or tomorrow to let the folks know I am still in the land of the living. There is no telling when we will start home. There are no signs of moving yet although there is a Reg't here (the 59 Ind.) that does part of our duty. We may leave by the 15th but not sooner.
Tullahoma, Sep [t]. 14

It is just four months today since we went into camp. The Hundred Day service is fast running into "for three years unless sooner discharged" and the boys are grumbling about it considerably. They think now that the road is opened and their time out, they should be sent home; and all the red tape from Gen. Milroy down to the Lieuts. of the companies receive a full share of blame for our detention. But Col. Robinson24 gets a double portion of anathemas. It is reported, with I don't know how much truth, that he offered the services of the Reg't. for another month. If the boys find out certainly that he did do [this], they will love him a great deal better than they do now, which is extraordinarily well.

We have beautiful weather here now, bright pleasant days and beautiful moonlight nights. So inviting indeed are both day & night that it makes one wish himself "out on the railroad sailing" towards the Christian land of Indiana, for such I must call it after living for nearly four months in this half-civilised and wholy demoralised clime called Tennessee . But such longings must not be indulged in or else I will be suspicioned of being homesick, and I do not wish to make any such an impression.
War Trace, Tenn. Thursday, Sep [t]. 15

Well we have started home at last and that rather unexpectedly too. When I wrote yesterday morning, there were no indications of our leaving; but about 3 P.M. the order was given to prepare our rations and be ready to move at 8 P.M. You had better believe the boys were not slow in obeying and everything was ready at the appointed time; and we were marched down to the depot but did not leave Tullahoma untill near 10 o'clock. And we have had rather an unlucky time since then. After running all night we
24 Colonel Edward J. Robinson of the 137th Indiana Regiment. Report of the Adjutant General of the State of Indiana, 111, 311.
only arrived here distant 14 miles from Tullahoma just before sun up; and by an unlucky accident by which two of our cars were thrown from the track we have been detained here all day (3 P.M.), and there is not much prospect of getting to Nashville soon. Several of the men hurt themselves by jumping from the cars.
Sept. 16 Some place on the L & N R.R. 94 miles from N[ashville]; 91 to L[ouisville]

We were more fortunate in getting off from War Trace than I anticipated. The reason we staid so long was because the locomotive got out of water and there were no tanks close [by]. As soon as the Col. found out what was the matter, he made a detail to go with the engine to a neighboring spring and fill up the tender. This was accomplished about dark yesterday, and at 9 o'clock we left Nashville arriving at daylight this morning.

It is now a little after 12 M., Friday, Sep[t]. 16. We left Nashville at 7 A.M. and are making good time toward Louisville. Lebanon Junction ½ past 4 P.M., Only 30 miles to Louisville . Will be there in a little over an hour. Have had a nice ride today. Our Co. are in passenger cars and if I wasn't so sleepy, would enjoy myself finely. Have had no sleep worth anything for the last two nights. If nothing unusual happens we will see Indiana before sundown.

Nearly all the guards along the road are Negroes. They are fine looking soldiers. They always turn out at a present arms when the train passes. Their accouterments and guns are bright as they can be, and the broad smile that marks their countenances attest their like of the change from Chattels to U. S. soldiers.
Louisville , Sep [t]. 17 Saturday morning.

We arrived here safely at sundown last night without accident of any kind. Some of our boys got left along the road, but they all got in last night. We got our suppers at the Soldiers' Home and were marched out on the commons where we had a nice sleep. We will probaly go to Indianapolis today but I don't know anything certain about it.

During the presidential campaign of 1836, a four-page campaign newspaper called the Tippecanoe Calumet Warclub, strongly advocating the election of William Henry Harrison, was published in Springfield, Clark County, Ohio , by J. D. Nichols. It was edited by the Whig Central Committee, which consisted of William V. H. Cushing, William A. Rogers, and James S. Halsey. The paper came out the last three months of the campaign, "weekly until the Presidential election." Subscriptions in advance were available at fifty cents; it was twenty cents a copy to clubs of five. The number of subscribers was about 2,500.

Four years later, in 1840, the publication of the Tippecanoe Calumet & War-Club was renewed by Jacob and John A. Crain. It, too, was published at Springfield , "under the patronage of the Harrison Association of Clark County ." Violently for Harrison and John Tyler, it was edited by the Whig Central Committee as before, with an increased circulation—the number of subscribers amounting to about 4,000. John D. Nichols was the agent. Subscriptions were $1.00, and there were to be twenty-six numbers.

The William Henry Smith Memorial Library of the Indiana Historical Society has in its collections material concerning the Tippecanoe Calumet Warclub consisting of letters and papers, principally the latter, dated January 30 to November 25, 1840, including a notebook containing a partial list of subscribers. Most of the items are subscription lists, or concern subscribers. The following letter to John A. Crain at Springfield, Ohio , is in the collection.

Yours from Lebanon came to hand, but I cannot promise you all that you might expect from so large a place as this.
* Eva Draegert is instructor in social studies, Woodruff High School, Peoria, Illinois . Information concerning the Tippecanoe Calumet and Warclub was furnished by Caroline Dunn, librarian of the William Henry Smith Memorial Library of the Indiana Historical Society, and the Western Reserve Historical Society,
Cleveland, Ohio , which has in its collections twelve copies of the paper. See also History of
Clark County, Ohio ., ( Chicago , 1881), 560, 561.
We, that is, our " Tippecanoe Club", and in fact all our Whig associations have quite as much as they can do with their own State, to enlighten, and rightly direct the ignorant and mulish population of the interior. I called on the corresponding Sec. of that association, and he expresses his willingness to aid if possible, the good cause of the "old Hero", but said that they were indebted largely, notwithstanding the very liberal donations they had received. That association has engaged to establish presses throughout the different sections of German population for the distribution of papers containing the Harrison principles, free of expenses, besides the printing and distributing, gratis, of twenty thousand English, and ten thousand German, copies of the life of Harrison, which is attended with a cost of 25 cents a copy. All these, (and they are no more than is required in order to carry the state), amount to a Herculean labor. All these things, and more being in view, the society respectfully declines advancing anything more, other than what their prayers and best wishes can advance the cause, and I trust in God they may be of some use.

I have, what moments of leisure I have had, got the names which I append, for the payment of which I will be responsible so soon as I have time to call on the parties, and maybe I may send you more; but the difficulties of the times, and the great dearth of business, together with my recent change, take the whole of my time so that I have not opportunity to give your communication that attention that I could wish. Moon Heyt No 195 Market St. 1 co. Spering Good No 138 Market St. 1 co. J. C. Doane 196 Market St. 1 co. J. E. Addicks 167 Market St. l co. Henry H. Reed 177 Market St. l co. W. H. Reed 177 Market St. 1 co. Truitt P. & Truitt 213 Market St. 1 co. H. C. Troutman 223 Market St. 1 co. E. W. Davidson 197 Market St., 1 co. R. B. Brinton 143 Market St. 1 co—J. M. Buck 49 Market St. 1 co. W. H. Campbell 21 Minor St. 1 copy Geo. Bolden 8 Commerce St. 1 co. C. W. Hollowell 7 North 4th St. 1 co. E. Walton 7 North 4th St. 1 co. Making
in all 29 copies subscribed, but 4 of those subscribed by our House; Fausset Kelly no. you need not send, but distribute wherever you think they will do the most good. I wish you all the success that I may pray for—But if you expect to get along, do in GODS name tear down that effeminate youth which you have at the head of your paper, to represent an an Indian! with a Calumet, and put something more appropriate in its place. That only excites ridicule—is not un-frequently compared to a "Green young Whig with his breeches down". Fill your paper with figures of "log Cabins"—"Hard-Cider" Barrels. Soldiers, Battles, Indians, Scalping females, and children—Houses in flames, etc. from the demoniac acts of savage barbarity. And you will then find that your paper will count, perhaps as much good as your most sanguine hearts could expect—Be assured that there is nothing in this world of such ready acceptance as "Humbug;" it is the order of the day and has more power even among men of strong minds and honest hearts, than we are willing to admit. Try it John, and you will find your advantage in it—And if it be not inconsistent with your pledges and other professions, advocate hard money, and cite the late suspension bill of the Locofoco legislation of Penna. as a bugbear—all of them are Humbugs of the first water, and will have their weight, if not of literal truth. The prospect of a War, too, and the probable destruction of property, and loss of [ms torn] from the ruthless Savages on our frontier, will be another fitting humbug, particularly when you put in juxtaposition the peculiar fitness of Genl. Harrison, from his known valor, and experience in indian warfare, with the effeminacy and draw-ingroom imbecility of present worthy humbug: Martin Van Buren. God prosper you is my most ardent wish.—I would write you more, but have not leisure, shall do so soon, in the mean time let me hear from you. I have not now, a moment to devote to social correspondence, but will some leisure Sunday, give you a savory dish.

div.head: Editor's Pages
div.p: The Indiana Magazine of History recently completed its first half-century of continuous publication. An historical sketch of the Magazine during this initial period appeared in the March issue, written by Emeritus Professor William O. Lynch, its editor from 1928 until 1941. In the latter year he was succeeded by Dr. John D. Barnhart, who served as editor until May 1, 1955.
The following paragraphs, taken verbatim from the opening remarks of Dr. Barnhart when he became editor, express basic ideas and concepts which are equally appropriate now:

"Various questions have been asked about the policies of the new editor. The first policy will be that of learning how to edit the Magazine as it has been edited. Consequently there will not be any important immediate changes nor any radical departures or thoughtless deviations from the past. When the business at hand is more fully understood there will be time enough to think about changes. The work of the previous editors is definitely appreciated and the first task is to do as well as they have done. That cannot be accomplished, however, without striving at the same time to make the Magazine better. Undoubtedly each of them strove constantly to make improvements, and therefore, to do as well means to try to do better. It is to be hoped that as time passes evidence of this effort will appear. Suggestions will always be appreciated whether it is possible to adopt them or not. Criticism, whether favorable or unfavorable, will also be welcome."1

Fortunately the retiring editor has left a number of articles available for publication and also a supply of books for review. This issue was almost ready for the printer on May 1, so that it is largely the result of the efforts of Dr. Barnhart and Miss Kathleen Nolan, his assistant editor.

As indicated on the cover, Professor Barnhart will become a member of the editorial committee. Professor Lynch will remain on this committee, as will Dr. Albert L. Kohlmeier, former chairman of the department of history and now professor emeritus of history. Mr. Hubert Hawkins, Director of the Indiana Historical Bureau and Secretary of the Indiana Historical Society, will likewise continue, illustrating
1 John D. Barnhart, "Editor's Pages," Indiana Magazine of History ( Bloomington , 1905-), XXXVII (1941), 287.
the co-operative relation which exists between the University, which owns the Magazine, and the historical agencies represented by Mr. Hawkins.

Professor R. C. Buley, a former managing editor of the Magazine, and a Pulitzer prize winner for his two volumes, The Old Northwest, 1815-1840 (originally published by the Indiana Historical Society in 1950) has become a member of the editorial committee. These gentlemen constitute an unusually strong editorial board, every one of whom values the Magazine and is much interested in its success. Moreover, since the Magazine is published by the department of history, the counsel and encouragement of Professor Harold J. Grim, the chairman of the department, will also be available. In fact, such aid has already been extended. Miss Frances Krauskopf is the associate editor of the Magazine.

The Magazine will continue to be devoted to the muse of Clio, but not in any narrow or provincial manner. It will endeavor to increase understanding and appreciation of the past, which is always the father of the present. Much is currently being said and written about the need to understand the world in which we live. The historian can do this more effectively by studying the experiences of men through the centuries, and by reflecting upon what may be called the historical process, than by losing his perspective in a rootless absorption with so-called contemporary history.

For instance, if one is eager to increase his understanding of the world today, a careful reading—and then rereadings—of the History of Thucydides can help to develop that depth of understanding about "current events" which can be derived only by an awareness of the continuity of human experience. In fact, the wisdom and insights which can be obtained from a faithful devotion to Clio are increasingly important. The editor is eager to keep the Magazine faithful to the best traditions of the historical craft and he hopes that numerous readers, both old and new, will continue to find the magazine interesting and worthwhile.

div.head: Book Reviews
Indian Corn in Old America. By Paul Weatherwax. ( New York : Macmillan, 1954, pp. vii, 253. Illustrations, bibliography, and index. $7.50)
div.p: For many years Paul Weatherwax, Professor of Botany at Indiana University, has been studying the morphology of corn and its relatives. Ten years ago he published a small booklet on this subject. It was well illustrated with line drawings of unusual clarity and comprehensibility. He spoke surely and effectively from a wealth of firsthand experience and a broad understanding of the techniques at his command. It was well received and demands for a new edition have been made.

In recent years Weatherwax has broadened his attack. He has read extensively in early historical accounts and has traveled in Central and South America and in the American Southwest to see firsthand some of the wonders of the world of corn. He found a number of items of interest and took some pictures of which he can be justly proud. The present volume is the author's attempt to popularize his earlier work and to include the results of his more recent historical reading and travels.

The book opens with several chapters devoted to a review of early historical references to the discovery of corn and its reception in Europe. (Africa is ignored and Asia relegated to incidental consideration in a later chapter.) Chapters seven to eleven deal with corn in America at the time of European discovery and early settlement. This anecdotal account is interesting reading and gives a good general impression of the corn agriculture of "the" Indian. One would have appreciated a botanical evaluation of some of the summary analyses which occur in the anthropological literature.

Chapters twelve through seventeen constitute a relatively popular review of the botanical theories about the origin and development of cultivated corn. The problem is a difficult one. The plant has been highly distorted under cultivation. The degree and direction of that distortion is a matter of debate. There are few, if any, close wild relatives. Written history is much too late to be of much significance. Archaeology has recently yielded materials of significant age but they are geographically marginal. In spite of the publication of a considerable volume of theory and the appearance of some
new critical material, the author adds little to the basic criticism in his former work, possibly because there is very little to add.

It is startling to find that after fifty years of active speculation about the origin of corn there is little real data, and, in the opinion of the present writer at least, no even remotely reliable conclusions. It is appalling, however, to find the current literature still clogged with (a) a theory which was negated soon after its publication in 1896, (b) a theory obviously misapplied by its originator and still of uncertain application, (c) a phantasmagoria of speculation "topheavy with assumptions of such character that if any one of them should be rejected the whole structure would fall" (p. 174), (d) a child's pottery rattle.

It is apparent that many of these "scientific conclusions" have been presented in response to a social pressure to conform to the prevailing anthropological theories, which were in turn influenced by a desire to conform to the prevailing botanical theories. Highly imaginative theories have survived, not just because they have been called "scientific," but because, gentle readers, we have found it convenient to believe them. Weatherwax has presented his own seemingly sane analysis of the current data, and has marked it, clearly, an alternative theory.
In the concluding chapter the author returns to the anecdotal theme, with a discussion of corn in Indian art, mythology, and religion.
The discussions are handsomely and appropriately illustrated with photographs, reproductions of early herbal plates, and all too few line drawings. There are seven pages of bibliography and an index.
The result is a beautiful book with many revealing insights and critical observations about the history of corn, its spread to Europe, and its use by early American Indians.

div.head: The Papers of Sir William Johnson, Volume XI. Edited by Milton W. Hamilton. ( Albany, New York : The State University of New York , 1954, pp. viii, 994. Illustrations. $5.25.)
div.p:
There is little new which can be said about a series now in its eleventh of twelve planned volumes plus one of addenda
and a cumulative index. But it is a pleasure to join in the chorus of praise for a work of historical craftsmanship so thorough and so useful. Had the title been less prosaic, say "The Life and Times of Sir William Johnson: The Triumph of the First British Empire in America," many would obtain a better idea of its true importance.

The theme of this volume is the years 1764 and 1765, when English self-satisfaction at the recent victory over France had been rudely shattered by the astounding success of Pontiac's rebellion. Sir William Johnson more than any other man was the architect of the rebuilding process which necessarily followed. The range of his correspondence shows how well fitted for the task he was; full and regular reports came to him from such military men as Thomas Gage, Henry Bouquet, Henry Montour, and Henry Gladwin, from provincial governors like Cadwallader Colden, John Penn, and Francis Fauquier, from members of his own administrative organization like John Stuart and George Croghan, from fur traders and land speculators, and, of course, from the Indians whose great friend he was. In an age when most Americans viewed the rights of man as synonymous with privileged status for the local community, Johnson possessed a truly national outlook.

As 1764 opened, the overshadowing concern was to pacify the Indians, recover white prisoners, and punish those responsible for the outbreak to the limited extent possible. First, Sir William drove the Iroquois cork even more firmly into the bottle of the still-smoldering Indian conspiracy. Then, despite such major hindrances as the murderous activities of the Paxton Boys, sabotage by land speculator-dominated colonial assemblies and the unpredictable behavior of military unit commanders, he proceeded methodically and with true artistry to utilize Indian diplomatic techniques in quieting successively the Senecas, the Miami-Shawnee- Delaware group, the Illinois Indians, and the far western fringe clear to Minnesota .

Johnson possessed a keen insight into the major ingredients of his explosive western mixture, which he reduced to the friction of three elements—the Indians, the land-hungry American whites, and the French fur traders. He had much sympathy with each group. Certainly the Americans should get the land, but slowly and peaceably. Toward
the Indians he extended a humanity which smacks of twentieth-century anthropology. Even while charging the French traders, correctly, with being the source of the dangerous rumors which had already sparked one explosion, he saw that they were behaving normally enough for persons in a desperately exposed position tortured by very real fears for their "job security." To each, Johnson would give a measure of satisfaction in order that lasting peace might prevail. As a power in the Indian world, he held a position never again to be equalled by a white man. Sir William served as a court of appeal for Indians everywhere, from his own Six Nations and their wide-ranging Algonkin foes to the pitiful remnant of Mohicans and Narragansetts almost submerged in the rising tide of Yankee population. All of them trusted his integrity even when they doubted his ability to deliver what was asked of him.

In his attitude toward "Pondiac," Johnson's willingness to forgive a wartime enemy seems more British than American. He agreed with Gage that Pontiac either should be won over, or "knocked in the head" (p. 250). When the Ottawa chieftain showed a disposition to repent having listened to the French, Johnson was willing to meet him halfway. By 1765, Alexander Fraser was describing Pontiac as "the most sensible man among all the Nations, and the most humane Indian I ever saw" (p. 743). Yet Sir William was always less Indian than white. When Governor Penn asked his advice about offering a bounty for Indian scalps in reprisal for certain frontier killings, Johnson answered with a very positive affirmative (pp. 224, 241). Always he made excellent use of his redskin levies to cut the need for expanding the blood and monies of his own people. And keeping the young braves from white-hunting was no easy job!

In March of 1765, and roughly two-thirds through this volume, the Stamp Act crisis of the eastern seaboard obtrudes into western affairs, with Colden writing Johnson about the "Insolence of persons in this Province [who] bawl out for Liberty [but] would cut a throat in the dark if they thought they could not be detected." (p. 620). Sir William's reaction was not difficult to predict. His long experience with the endless clashes between Indians and eastern land grabbers, whether big or small, had led him to regard the one as no whit more cruel or faithless than the
other. His soldier friends regarded Provincials as "but a poor Security" (p. 231). That he would stand with the Imperial Government on Stamp Act issues he makes quite clear in a letter of July 12, 1765, written to Gage (pp. 930-932). All good men should come to the aid of their nation, not of their locality.

Who was the greater danger, the Indian or the frontiersman, to peace in the West is hard to say. But it is easy enough to see why the British government inclined to the Indian side. For it was abundantly evident at all times that Americans had not the slightest agreement with Johnson's position that Indian and white were equals under the law, that a white murderer of a redskin should be hanged just as readily as an Indian who killed a white (p. 791). Both Johnson and his capable agent, George Croghan, were thoroughly fed up with this situation by June, 1765.

To conclude on a less somber note, one observes with a certain bitter pleasure that apparently rather more whites, proportionately, deserted to the Indians during the eighteenth century than have renegaded to the assorted communist "tribes" of today. Nor are the Johnson Papers without a touch of humor here and there. For a good chuckle, Croghan's letter of fatherly advice to young John Johnson on departing for the fleshpots of London can be highly recommended (pp. 964-965). Another example: Rum was John-son's "milk" to the Indians, and with the embarrassing directness characteristic of children everywhere they asked him why it should be good for the white man but bad for them. Needless to say, no reply was forthcoming.
